chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected Gilbert's syndrome?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a person has suspected Gilbert's syndrome:

  • Ask about symptoms suggestive of underlying liver disease, such as abdominal pain, itch, pale stools, and dark urine.
    • If symptoms are present, consider further investigations or management as appropriate, depending on clinical judgement. See the CKS topic on Jaundice in adults for further information.
  • Examine the person:
    • There may be mild jaundice and signs of precipitating factors such as dehydration or intercurrent infection.
    • There should be no hepatosplenomegaly or signs of chronic liver disease. If present, see the CKS topic on Jaundice in adults for further information.
  • Arrange blood tests:
    • Liver function tests (LFTs) with unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin levels — should show unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia (conjugated bilirubin within the normal range and/or less than 20% of total bilirubin) and other LFT results should be normal.
      • Note: send the blood sample wrapped (for example, in a small envelope) to reduce light exposure which may lead to conjugation.
    • Full blood count (FBC) with reticulocyte count and blood film to exclude haemolysis — should be normal.
  • Gilbert's syndrome can be diagnosed if a person has:
    • Confirmed unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia (often noted on several occasions).
    • Otherwise normal LFTs.
    • No evidence of haemolysis.
    • No evidence of other liver disease.
  • If there is any clinical uncertainty, discuss with a gastroenterologist or hepatologist.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
History taking

  • The recommendation on asking about symptoms of liver disease is based on expert opinion in a review article [Claridge, 2011] and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

Examination findings

  • The recommendation on examining the person to exclude other possible causes of liver disease is based on expert opinion in the chapter on Jaundice in the Oxford textbook of medicine [Thompson, 2010] and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

Blood tests to arrange

  • The recommendations on blood tests to arrange to confirm the diagnosis of Gilbert's syndrome is based on expert opinion in the chapter on Jaundice in the Oxford textbook of medicine [Thompson, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article [Claridge, 2011] and a regional clinical guideline [Hudson and McPherson, 2014].
  • The information to wrap the blood sample when checking serum unconjugated bilirubin levels to stop light exposure, is based on expert opinion in a regional clinical guideline [Hudson and McPherson, 2014].
  • CKS notes that people with Gilbert's syndrome will have a 2- to 3-fold increase in serum unconjugated bilirubin level if they are fasted, which should return to normal after restarting a normal diet [Hudson and McPherson, 2014; BMJ, 2015]. However expert opinion in a review article states that reduced caloric intake tests have low diagnostic specificity in people with suspected Gilbert's syndrome [Sticova and Jirsa, 2013]. Similarly, a review article states that Gilbert's syndrome can be diagnosed after a 48 hour fast, but the diagnosis is typically made after excluding other causes of raised unconjugated bilirubin [Smellie and Ryder, 2006]. CKS has therefore not recommended this diagnostic approach in primary care.
